headline.main: NEWS FROM WASHINGTON.; ALL QUIET ALONG THE UNION LINES. Capture of a Party of Rebels on the Left Wing. IMPORTANT INFORMATION IMPARTED. Increased Demoralization in the Rebel Army. Ominous Disaffection in South Carolina. The Allotments of the New-York Troops. COL. KERRIGAN'S TRIAL RESUMED Immense Preparations for the Manufacture of Firearms. PASSES FOR THE SOUTH. GEN. PATTERSON. A SOLDIER SHOT. THE NEW-YORK ALLOTMENTS. THE CASE OF COL. BENHAM. THE KERRIGAN TRIAL. MANUFACTURE OF FIRE-ARMS. THE GOVERNMENT PRINTING BUREAU. ARRIVAL OF RICHMOND PRISONERS. AN ABSENCE, AND PROBABLY A WEDDING. THE LOWER POTOMAC. MILEAGE OF MEMBERS OF CONGRESS. A LECTURE BY HORACEE GREELEY. THE CLAIMS AGAINST NEW-GRANADA. THE NEW-YORK BANK COMMITTEE.

docs.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Friday, Jan. 3. AN IMPORTANT DISCOVERY. It is said that circumstances have transpired within the past few days, leading to the belief that it will not be difficult to designate with certainty the source whence the rebels have, within the last two months, derived most valuable information, which it is known the Government took every means to conceal.

headline.main: OUR PORT ROYAL CORRESPONDENCE.; A SOLDIER KILLED ON TYBEE ISLAND BY A SHOT FROM FORT PULASKI-IMPROVEMENTS IN PROGRESS-WHY NO ADVANCE CAN BE MADE.

docs.abstract: Reports from Port Royal and Tybee Island, Ga
docs.lead_paragraph: HILTON HEAD, S. C., Monday, Dec. 30, 1861. The steamer Ben. Deford has just arrived from Tybee Island, whither she carried subsistence stores for the troops. The health of the command is reported to be good. A soldier named Mona, belonging to the Forty-Sixth New-York Regiment, Col. ROSA'S, was killed yesterday by a round shot from Fort Pulaski. He and several of his comrades had sauntered

headline.main: NEWS OF THE DAY.; THE REBELLION.

docs.lead_paragraph: A telegram from Halifax gives currency to the terrible rumor that the British steamship Parana, with eleven hundred troops on board, had been lost in the St. Lawrence River. The rumor has not been traced to any reliable source, but there is a possibility that it may be true. The hurricane of New-Year's night was very severo in that latitude.

headline.main: LETTER FROM CAMP ANDERSON.; CHRISTMAS DAY IN CAMP--CHANGES AMONG THE STAFF OFFICERS--RUMORS OF A MOVEMENT, ETC.

docs.lead_paragraph: If any of our friends in New-York, while enjoying their Christmas dinner, gave a thought to us poor regulars, and wondered how we fared on that great feast day, it will rejoice them to know that we fared as sumptuously as any men of well regulated minds could possibly desire. Our company commanders behaved in a most liberal manner, thereby ...

docs.snippet: Spanish expedition occupies Vera Cruz; Mexican Gov. issues proclamation ordering city evacuated

headline.main: THE EXPEDITION TO MEXICO.; Arrival of the Spanish Division Before Vera Cruz. The City and Castle Abandoned by the Mexican Authorities. Vera Cruz in Possession of the Spaniards.
